steps.title: Obtain the okra.
steps.content: Obtain the okra. You can buy okra from many fruit and vegetable suppliers. Make sure that the okra is fresh. While it may be difficult to harvest your own okra , it is possible and proves inexpensive.

steps.title: Choose okra that is evenly green and about 2 to 4 inches (5-10 cm) long.
steps.content: Choose okra that is evenly green and about 2 to 4 inches (5-10 cm) long. Too large and the okra will have a flat taste, and may be too tough to eat. Too small, and the okra will be difficult to cook. Avoid okra that look shriveled or are soft when squeezed. The okra should snap rather than bend.

steps.title: Trim the stem end.
steps.content: Trim the stem end. Do this without cutting the pod itself. The conical stem attached to the pod can be carefully trimmed around to remove if desired. Remove the thin layer with your fingers. Doing this ensures that the whole vegetable is edible but it is time-consuming to do.

steps.title: Defuzz okra.
steps.content: Defuzz okra. The fuzziness on okra doesn't have to be removed before cooking on young okra. To remove it from older okra: Defuzz under running water. Rub the pod gently using a fine nylon scourer, paper towel, or a vegetable brush. [1] X Research source Pat the okra dry inside a dishcloth or spread it out to air dry.

steps.title: Prevent okra from becoming slimy during cooking.
steps.content: Prevent okra from becoming slimy during cooking. This can be done by giving the okra a vinegar treatment, although you will need to do this well in advance. [2] X Research source Pour half a cup of vinegar into a bowl for every 500 g (1 lb) of okra. Gently swish the vinegar over the okra to coat all okra in the bowl. Leave for 30 minutes to soak in the vinegar. Remove the okra and rinse well. Dry and use as suggested by the recipe.

steps.title: Know how to prepare the okra for different dishes.
steps.content: Know how to prepare the okra for different dishes. There are different ways to prepare okra depending on how it is being cooked: Slice into even-sized pieces for Cajun and Creole stews (e.g., gumbo) that are thickened using okra after topping and tailing it. Cut into slices or leave whole for frying (see below). Leave whole (but cleaned and prepared) for stews and casseroles where the recipe requires this. If the okra is cooked whole, it is not able to release its gelatinous substance. [3] X Research source If using as a thickener, blanch the whole okra first. Slice the okra and add to the dish 10 minutes before cooking time finishes. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Use garlic and spices with okra.
steps.content: Use garlic and spices with okra. Okra goes well with eggplant, onions, peppers, and tomatoes. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Cut off the stems.
steps.content: Cut off the stems. These are tough, with little flavor; see the instructions above.

steps.title: Slice the okra in 1/4 inch (6.35mm) slices.
steps.content: Slice the okra in 1/4 inch (6.35mm) slices. If you cut them too thick, they will take longer to cook.

steps.title: Beat an egg
steps.content: Beat an egg and soak the okra in this for about 5 to 10 minutes.

steps.title: While that's soaking, put about a cup of cornmeal in a dish with salt and pepper.
steps.content: While that's soaking, put about a cup of cornmeal in a dish with salt and pepper. Don't use flour, as this will cake up and the okra will end up mushy. [6] X Research source

steps.title: After soaking for a while, dredge the slices in the cornmeal, covering evenly.
steps.content: After soaking for a while, dredge the slices in the cornmeal, covering evenly. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Heat about a 1/2 a cup of oil in a skillet on medium to high heat.
steps.content: Heat about a 1/2 a cup of oil in a skillet on medium to high heat.

steps.title: When the oil is hot, carefully place the okra into the pan.
steps.content: When the oil is hot, carefully place the okra into the pan.

steps.title: Stir continuously, making sure it doesn't burn.
steps.content: Stir continuously, making sure it doesn't burn. Fry the okra for 2 minutes until golden, take it out and let drain on paper towels. Enjoy. [8] X Research source
